article.description:
There was the Creighton forward hitting
a key jump shot in the closing minutes.
article.headline: Korver knocks down two key late 3-pointers in win
article.linkText: Korver, Grimes spark Creighton past SMS
article.story: SPRINGFIELD, Mo. (AP) -- There was the Creighton forward hitting a key jump shot in the closing minutes. Then he was at the other end, challenging shots and ripping down rebounds. And there he was again on offense, making a couple of clutch free throws. Oh, and Kyle Korver had a big game too. Korver, Creighton's star senior forward, got hot when it counted, hitting two late 3-pointers and scoring 23 points as the (No. 18 ESPN/USA Today, No. 17 AP) Bluejays rallied to beat Southwest Missouri State 63-58 on Wednesday night. But Creighton (25-3, 14-2 Missouri Valley) couldn't have managed its record-breaking -- and nation-leading -- 25th win without backup forward Mike Grimes, who went 8-for-11 from the line and scored 14 points. "That's where he really hurt us -- at the line,'' said Southwest Missouri State coach Barry Hinson, whose team lost despite a 22-point performance by guard Terrance McGee. "Their big guy gets to the line 11 times, our two big guys go 2-for-5. That was a big difference in the game.'' But at halftime, Grimes was wondering if he'd even get a chance to make an impact. Despite six points -- four in the last 1:12 of the half -- Creighton coach Dana Altman wasn't pleased with Grimes' play. "I know that I wasn't playing a great game,'' Grimes said. "Coach told me he could go with somebody else if I didn't step up. It was on my shoulders.'' The Bluejays really needed a big game from Grimes on Wednesday, because they got just one point from the rest of their starting frontcourt. Forward Michael Lindeman went scoreless and center Brody Deren hit one free throw, although Lindeman had eight rebounds and Deren blocked four shots. Each had been averaging 8.2 points per game. "I just couldn't get anything to fall,'' Deren said. "Luckily, Mike was able to get his to fall.'' It was the second comeback win over Southwest Missouri State (15-10, 11-5) this year for Creighton, which was down by nine points at halftime and needed overtime to beat the Bears 70-67 two weeks ago. For Southwest Missouri State, Wednesday night's loss followed a disheartening pattern. Of their 10 defeats this season, seven have been by five points or less. "That's eating at us,'' McGee said. "Every team that gets close in this many games gets tired of losing.'' Creighton, which trailed by four points at halftime and by as many as eight points early in the second half on Wednesday night, took a 50-49 lead on Korver's 3-pointer with 6:39 left. The Bears answered with Tamarr Maclin's basket and McGee's leaner to go up 53-50, but Grimes' jumper and Korver's 3-pointer made it 57-54 with 3:08 left. McGee twice got Southwest Missouri State within one point, the last time on a basket with 27 seconds left that cut the margin to 59-58. But Korver hit two free throws with 23 seconds remaining and Grimes went 2-for-4 from the line over the final 10 seconds. Larry House had 10 points for the Bluejays. Merrill Andrews added 16 points for Southwest Missouri State, and Maclin had 10 rebounds. Korver's third 3-pointer of the first half gave Creighton a 23-21 lead with 4:46 left, but the Blue Jays didn't manage another field goal until Grimes hit a follow shot with 32 seconds left. "For us to shoot 38 percent and win -- I'll take that,'' Altman said. "Our kids just found a way to get it done tonight.''
